title: What would the universe be like without gravity? - Quora

response.answer_text: From the big bang moment or just all of a sudden, no more gravity? The first case is almost impossible to conceive.  Minds much greater than mine do not understand how gravity really works, nor does anyone have full understanding of that awesome "let there be light" moment.  My logic tells me that that would have pretty much been it.  Just one incredibly bright flash of light that no one would ever see. There could be no mass.  Whatever might form, would be massless  and continue at the speed of light which might  or might not be the same  as it is in this universe with the basic fundamental constants of the universe having been so profoundly messed with. The second thought of instantaneous weight loss is more fun to think about, but it would be terrifying for the few moments before you died.  The Earth's atmosphere would almost instantly be sucked into the vacuum of space as everything not firmly fastened to Earth's surface headed skyward, being thrown off by the centrifugal force of the Earth's rotation.  People, vehicles, buildings, boulders, animals, and all manner of debris would suddenly be set adrift in space.      And the oceans, OMG! Before the water froze  it would swirl over the land in the most astounding tsunami imaginable flying skyward with fish and whales and all of its life quickly going into the final deep freeze.      Earth, just spinning, no longer orbiting the sun would be on a lone path through the universe casting off bits of itself for a short while.  Short because it would not outdistance the Sun in time to escape the consequences suddenly having no gravity would produce there.  Stars are held together by gravity and it is the gravity that allows nuclear fusion to proceed.  All that heat and energy pushing outward with nothing to restrain it?  Kaboom!!!!   And then its atomic fires would cease functioning as the sun expanded, very quickly moving beyond all the former orbits of the planets, probably at or near light speed, making toast of the planets that had not drifted far enough away.  That might be all of them.  The gas giants, Jupiter and friends, might not even be giants anymore, just gas.  The same thing would be happening everywhere  else in the universe, though the awesome, short-lived spectacle would take years to reveal itself to any aliens who were lucky enough to be in an unaffected region of space. How would this affect black holes?  WOW!  That's quite a thought.  I suppose all the light that couldn't escape before, would suddenly have no more constraints.  Black hole explosions would dwarf those of the stars.  The super-massive central black holes of galaxies would release enough radiation to disintegrate almost anything that was still frozen and hanging together by chemical bonds or crystalline structures.  It would be quite awesome to view.  There might also be a sudden change in the universe's expansion.  Either it would suddenly stop or suddenly be completely out of control.  Your guess is good as mine. The bottom line.  Complete and utter devastation of the entire universe.

The Universe will not exist without gravity. Gravity is a binding force continuously acting to bind matter. The Big Bang generated lots of energy flying in all directions. Gravitons , the particles mediating the force of gravity, absorbed almost most of the energy released by the Big Bang. There were no other particles. Gravitons started biding together to make particles, the first they made was a proton. An electron was a by-product of making protons. Sometimes electrons collapsed on protons and made neutrons which are composite particles, not stable if left alone. Then gravitons combined these particles to make atoms of hydrogen gas. The force of gravity is least understood among all fundamental forces. It is regarded as the weakest force in the Universe. That is not the case. If we consider the examples/events in the Universe caused by gravity, we can conclude that it is the strongest force in the Universe. It is this force that gave birth to all the stars in the Universe, all the galaxies in the Universe. We see the structure in the Universe that is due to gravity only. This Universe exist due to gravity. It is this force that squeezes hydrogen atoms in the belly of stars to ignite fusion reaction. Lots of energy is released from strong force within atoms. Explosions, neutrons, protons flying, rising temperature, yet gravity keeps the star intact and spherical. No other force including strong force, electromagnetic or weak nuclear force , no matter how strong and large, can counter act the force of gravity in stars. Indeed, gravity is the strongest fundamental force in the Universe. This Universe only exist due to gravity.

I suppose one can imagine a universe without gravity (unless one happens to be a GR theorist), but it would certainly be a big, boring universe. Big because, without gravity, it would have been expanding faster for the past 13.4 billion years. Boring because, without gravity, we would never have emerged from the “Dark Ages” after Recombination — all the hydrogen and helium atoms would just have followed their individual trajectories, occasionally bouncing off each other, but never forming stars; as a result, no nuclei heavier than helium would ever have had a chance to form (and probably only a very small trace of helium, at that!). e.e. cummings would not have wanted to go there.

A galaxy? No. Galaxies are formed by the gentle gravitational forces. However, it's a moot point. Gravity is omnipresent; there is no where in our Universe that had an absence of gravity, so a galaxy without it is meaningless. Our Universe? No, gravity is present, so the question is moot. A universe? We just don't know. We have only a single data point from which to extrapolate and we don't know all that much about even that. We could conjecture other universes that lack gravity, but we just don't know enough yet to take such thought experiments beyond speculation. As others have said, the balance of fundamental properties of our universe is quite fine, with little room for variation without our universe failing. It's likely that there are other metastable conditions, but we have no real means to test any hypothesis.

Can the universe exist without gravity? Sure it can, but not like it exists currently. Gravity is responsible for things like planets, stars, star systems, galaxies, clusters and super clusters. The only elements present would be lots of hydrogen, maybe some helium and lithium, but without stars, no other elements would form. The matter in the universe would fly out at incredible speeds at the Big Bang, and without gravity, nothing would hold it back, so space would be even emptier than it is now. Basically, the universe would have existed for a mere blink of the eye before suffering near immediate heat death.

Can the universe exist without mind? By all accounts, based on CTMU theory of Langan, and Wheeler’s Participatory Universe, it cannot (or it cannot be stated). We as observers “give” the universe its existence in a backtrack fashion (based on Wheeler’s backtrack path mind experiment). But before we came to be, in what state was the universe? Strikingly and based on the above theories, it was in an indeterminate state! Thus, there was matter, but no determinate universe. It boils down to definition of existence: does a possibility, by its manifestation, becomes more real than it was? According to Tesla, “gravity” is an electromagnetic effect.

I just finished my “Paddle Wheel Theory” that includes this topic. A universe DOES exist without any gravity, but only a short (instantaneous) time…. as the very moment of a big bang. A big bang is the point where all “things” exist as energy; since gravity is a bi-product of mass and matter begins to appear then (albeit small), there is… and always must be… of varying amounts.

Q: Can a universe exist without gravity? A: When you start playing around with the values of the physical constants, including gravity, you get conditions under which universes would be very short-lived, either collapsing back into themselves almost immediately after their big bang, or expanding to nothingness quickly after their big bang. A stable universe existing for a long time, such as ours, would not be conceivable without gravity.

There were no masses per se, so what is today the intrinsic property of mass [called “gravity”], did not exists as such. With the formation of particles having mass, comes then gravity in the traditional roll as an implicit consequence thereof. So in one sense, there has always been a negative energy field, but in the NOW state of the universe, the roll of gravity is better defined.
